SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

net.java.jddac.jmci.units
Class Unit

java.lang.Object
  net.java.jddac.jmci.units.Unit

public class Unit
extends java.lang.Object

A physical unit, such as horsepower. Physical quantities are often represented as {number, unit} pairs, like "0.8 kilograms". This class is intended to support implementation of such pairs.

A unit is associated with a dimension (see Dimension), such as mass, length, etc. The associated dimension determines which unit conversions are legal, and serves to advise a Quantity package which quantities can be added and compared.

A unit has a scale type (see ScaleType), such as ratio, offset, logarithmic, etc. This determines the way in which the unit maps physical quantities to numbers. The scale type serves to advise a Quantity package whether certain operations would be legal (adding Kelvin temperatures is, but adding Fahrenheit temperatures is not), and the effect of certain operations (adding quantities in dBm has the same effect as multiplying quantities in watts).

A unit has a converter (see Converter) for converting the numeric part of a Quantity to the associated SI unit (e.g. from weeks to seconds). This, together with the fact that a converter has an inverse, provide a conversion path between any legal pair of units.

A unit has a name, and zero or more aliases. In the spirit of being liberal in what we accept and strict in what we produce, the name is used on output, and the union of name and aliases is accepted on input. The name actually comes in three forms: singular, plural and abbreviation. A Formatter can distinguish between the full and abbreviated forms as users desire or display space dictates. Note that good usage requires that the long/short form be matched between name and prefix, and among all elements of a name. Thus, millimeter/second is legal, but mmeter/second is not, nor is millimeter/s. The singular and plural forms are available so that a Quantity package can say "1 foot" instead of "1 feet." Finally, since the rules allow the SI scale prefixes to be applied only to SI units ("milliyards" is not allowed (though "micro-inches" has made it into practice)), a unit keeps track of whether or not it is SI.

The function Unit.initialize() must be called at startup. That generates the SI base units: METER, KILOGRAM, SECOND, AMPERE, KELVIN, MOLE, CANDELA, RADIAN and STERADIAN. All other SI units can be created from these by multiplication, division and exponentiation. All non-SI units can be created from the SI units by applying the appropriate converter.

NONE

public static final Unit NONE
Unit for the "none of the above" dimension. SI doesn't recognize this, but completeness requires one, so we claim it's SI.

Method Detail

getInstance

protected static Unit getInstance(Unit candidate)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Factory method which operates from a scratch unit. If not found, register it and return it. If found, register names as needed, then return the pre-existing unit.

Parameters:
candidate - The scratch unit
Returns:
A unit, known to be unique, equals to u
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if one or more names are already in use
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

getInstance

public static Unit getInstance(Dimension d,
                               java.lang.String singular,
                               java.lang.String plural,
                               java.lang.String abbrev,
                               boolean isSI,
                               int scaleType)
                        throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Factory method for new unit, given all parameters.

Parameters:
d - The associated dimension (e.g. speed is associated with knot)
singular - The singular name of the unit, e.g. "foot". All lowercase
plural - The plural name of the unit, e.g. "feet"
abbrev - The abbreviation of the unit's name, e.g. "ft". No trailing period
isSI - True iff this is an SI unit
scaleType - The unit's ScaleType
Returns:
an existing Unit with the given parameters, if any, otherwise creates a new Unit and returns that. If an existing unit matches all the non-string parameters, the existing unit is returned and the provided strings are added to the unit's string representations, as if with addName.

Note that users can't create base units; those are predefined. Users can add names to base units if they wish.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

                               java.lang.String abbrev,

                               int scaleType)

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

getInstance

public static Unit getInstance(java.lang.String name)
Look up a unit by its name.

Parameters:
name -
Returns:
A previously-defined unit with the given name, in the singular or plural or abbrev field. If none is found, return null. If more than one is found, return an arbitrary one.

getInstance

public static Unit getInstance(Unit parent,
                               Converter toParent,
                               java.lang.String singular,
                               java.lang.String plural,
                               java.lang.String abv)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Return a unit derived from a unit and a Converter, specifying the ScaleType of the result.

Parameters:
parent - The parent unit.
toParent - A constructor for converting back from the unit being derived to parent.
Returns:
the derived unit. If such a unit already exists, we return it; otherwise a new unit is constructed.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if one or more names is already in use

initialize

public static void initialize()
This method must be called before any use is made of the units package. Upon its return the system knows the basis units and their associated dimensions, and does not know any other units or dimensions. Subsequent calls to this method have no effect (but see reInitialize).

reInitialize

public static void reInitialize()
This method is just like initialize except that it is not idempotent. Calling this causes the package to forget all known units and dimensions except the basis ones.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Return a simple string identifying this unit. Intended for debugging. The proper way to convert a unit to a string is by a Formatter.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

                  java.lang.String singular,
                  java.lang.String plural,
                  java.lang.String abbrev)
           throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Construct the product of this unit and another. As a side effect, the associated dimension is constructed (with a default name), if needed.

Parameters:
u - the other unit
singular - the singular name of the result, e.g. foot-pound
plural - the plural name of the result, e.g. foot-pounds
abbrev - the abbreviation for the result, e.g. ft-lb (no '.')
Returns:
the product unit. A new unit is constructed as needed.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

Returns:
the new unit. A new unit is constructed as needed.

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

root

public Unit root(int p)
          throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Take the nth root of this unit, e.g.  meter^3 to meter^1.5, choosing default names for the result. As a side effect, the associated dimension is created if needed. The reason a pair of methods -- raise and root -- rather than a single one, is so that the exponents can be integers.

Returns:
the new unit. A new unit is constructed as needed.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

root

public Unit root(int p,
                 java.lang.String singular,
                 java.lang.String plural,
                 java.lang.String abbrev)
          throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Take the nth root of this unit, e.g.  meter^3 to meter^1.5. As a side effect, the associated dimension is created (with a default name) if needed. The reason a pair of methods -- raise and root -- rather than a single one, is so that the exponents can be integers. *

Parameters:
singular - the name of the resulting unit
plural - the plural name of the resulting unit
abbrev - the abbreviation of the resulting unit, e.g. m^2
Returns:
the new unit. A new unit is constructed as needed.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

isCompatibleWith

public boolean isCompatibleWith(Unit u)
Tell whether two units are compatible, in the sense that a converter could be written to convert quantities from one to the other.

Parameters:
u -
Returns:
true iff it would be legal to convert between this unit and u. For example, meter/second and knot are compatible, whether or not we know how to do the conversion. Meter/second and liter are incompatible. Different specializations of a dimension are considered compatible.

getDimension

public Dimension getDimension()
Return the dimension this unit is associated with

getScaleType

public int getScaleType()
Return this unit's ScaleType

getSiUnit

public Unit getSiUnit()
Return the SI unit associated with this unit. The SI unit associated with knot, for example, is meter/second.

getConverterToSi

public Converter getConverterToSi()
Return a converter from this unit to the associated SI unit.

public Converter getConverterTo(Unit that)

Return a converter from this unit to the given unit.

Parameters:
that - The unit to convert to
Returns:
a converter from this unit to that
Throws:
ConversionException

toSi

public double toSi(double val)
Convert a value from this unit to the associated SI unit.

fromSi

public double fromSi(double val)
Convert a value from the SI unit associated with this unit to this unit. If the pu is a unit of pressure, for example, pu.fromSI(6) would convert from 6 pascals to pu.

toSIInterval

public double toSIInterval(double val)
Convert the value of an interval (typically an uncertainty) from this unit to the associated SI unit. This is useful for units, such as Celsius, with OFFSET scale type. An uncertainty of 1 degree Celsius is not equal to an uncertainty of 273 degrees Kelvin.

fromSIInterval

public double fromSIInterval(double val)
Convert the value of an interval (typically an uncertainty) from the associated SI unit to this unit. This is useful for units, such as Celsius, with OFFSET scale type. An uncertainty of 1 degree Celsius is not equal to an uncertainty of 273 degrees Kelvin.

getSingularName

public java.lang.String getSingularName()
Return the singular name for this unit, e.g.  "foot".

getPluralName

public java.lang.String getPluralName()
Return the plural name for this unit, e.g.  "feet".

getAbbrev

public java.lang.String getAbbrev()
Return the abbreviation for this unit, e.g.  "ft". The SI calls this the unit's "symbol".

addAlias

public void addAlias(java.lang.String alias)
              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Supply an additional name for a unit. An alias is only used for parsing -- not for display -- so we don't distinguish among singular, plural and abbreviation. An alias must not duplicate any other unit's alias, nor any other unit's singular name, plural name, or abbreviation.

Parameters:
alias - An additional name for this unit, eg "Foot" for the unit whose name is "foot".
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if alias is already used by another unit. No error and no effect if it is already associated with this unit.

allUnits

public static java.util.Collection allUnits()
Return all known units, including specializations

Returns:
a new (unsynchronized) Collection containing the units.

allUnits

public static java.util.Collection allUnits(Dimension d)
Return all the units associated with a given dimension or its specializations. Units associated with ancestors of d are not returned.

Parameters:
d - The dimension
Returns:
A new (unsynchronized) Collection containing the units.

siUnitForDimension

public static Unit siUnitForDimension(Dimension d)
Look up the SI unit for a given dimension. If there is more than one, return a randomly-chosen one

Parameters:
d - the dimension
Returns:
the associated SI unit, or null

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Units are equals if they have the same dimension and scale type, and their conversion functions are close enough.
